FacilityName: Helena Agri-Enterprises, LLC- Bluffs, IL Facility
FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft or Terrorism
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Pneumatic actuated internal and ESO valves; Riser Valves; Bulkhead
_prev_prog_2.CH_OtherChanges: Installed pneumatic actuated ESOs and Internal Valve; and install Y-Strainer.
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Pressure Vessel, process piping, pump, valves, and transfer hoses
_prev_prog_2.Description:
The Crop Advisor implements the Risk Management Plan (RMP) and Risk Management Program (RMPr) for the Storage & Handling of anhydrous ammonia at this Facility and is assisted by other Facility staff as directed.  The RMPr describes the Accident Prevention Program that includes Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, and Emergency Response.  



This Facility stores and handles anhydrous ammonia in a single stationary pressure vessel (PV).  The covered process equipment includes: one 18,000-gallon stationary PV and ancillary process piping, valves, liquid pump, gauges (volume and pressure), safety systems (excess flow valves, emergency shutoff valves, internal valves, backflow check valve, bulkhead, and breakaway equipment).  



The Facility receives anhydrous ammonia by a Contractor that transports the anhydrous ammonia with a commercial tanker truck.  The commercial tanker truck is temporarily parked on the Facility property while the anhydrous ammonia is transferred to the stationary PVs.  The Contractor performs the transfer of anhydrous ammonia from the commercial tanker truck to the stationary PVs.  The Facility does not own or operate the commercial tanker truck.  The Contractor is responsible for training their operators and maintaining their equipment.  At a minimum, the Contractor must (1) have in place and certify compliance with applicable and relevant DOT, OSHA, state and local regulatory requirements, (2) make available to the Facility and EPA upon request any contractor-related documentation necessary to demonstrate compliance, and (3) certify that it has in place emergency shut-down procedures for anhydrous ammonia transfer operations.  The Facility coordinates with the Contractor on Emergency Contingency procedures and will provide access to the Facility RMPr upon request by the Contractor.



Trained Process Operators operate the covered process which includes the: (1) monitoring of volume and pressures during storage; and (2) transfer of anhydrous ammonia from the stationary PVs to nurse tanks.  These operations are conducted in accordance with the RMPr Operating Procedures.  The Facility stores and maintains all nurse tanks at the Branch location (Meredosia, IL).  Empty Nurse Tanks are shuttled from Meredosia, IL to Bluffs, IL upon seasonal demand.  Nurse Tanks are returned to Meredosia, IL when the season is complete.  Trained personnel perform maintenance on this covered process in accordance with the RMPr Maintenance Procedures.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: This is a non-responding facility and it coordinates its response activities with the LEPC and local Fire Department. Notification information and procedures are provided in its Contingency Plan.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Helena Agri-Enterprises, LLC Bluffs, IL Facility has submitted this updated electronic RMP in compliance with the provisions of the Clean Air Act 112 (r) as codified by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency at 40 CFR Part 68.  Standards codified by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration at 29 CFR 1910.119 are not applicable to the operations at this facility because the facility is operated as a retail operation and is exempt from the OSHA standards.  However, the OSHA standards at 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, are applicable and are included in the Risk Management Program (RMPr) document that is implemented by this Facility.  This electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident, and to ensure that a response to a release will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



The Facility is submitting this as a 5-year update in accordance with the rule.  All accident prevention elements have been reviewed and/or updated.  



FACILITY



The operations at this Facility consist of agricultural fertilizer retail.  The Facility operates one (1) covered process that includes Storage and Handling of anhydrous ammonia.  Anhydrous ammonia is transported to this Facility by a Contractor owned and operated commercial tanker truck.  The Contractor transfers anhydrous ammonia from the commercial tanker truck to one 18,000-gallon stationary pressure vessels (PV).  



The Facility stores the anhydrous ammonia in the stationary PV and then transfers the anhydrous ammonia from the PVs to nurse tanks at the point of retail sale to the end user (i.e. Grower/Farmer).  Trained Process Operators perform the transfer of anhydrous ammonia in accordance with its RMPr accident prevention program.    



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case and alternative case consequence analyses were completed for the single covered process that i

s operated at this Facility.  The worst case release scenario assumes that all the contents in the largest single PV (i.e. 18,000 gallons) are released.   The release scenario consists of the PV being punctured on the side at the ground level and the release is modeled as a ground level horizontal jet.



The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario assumes a 30-second release from a violent rupture of a 3-inch transfer hose caused by an impact or pull-away during a transfer operation.  This alternative scenario considers active mitigation of the safety equipment (i.e. emergency shutoff and excess flow valves on the commercial tanker truck; and emergency shutoff, backpressure check and excess flow valves on the PV side of the bulkhead), and operating procedures that the Facility uses to safeguard against releases from ammonia transfer operations.



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Crop Advisor implements the risk management planning process at this Facility.  The Crop Advisor is assisted by other Facility staff, as directed.  The Crop Advisor is responsible for ensuring that Facility Staff are properly trained in the implementation of the Prevention Program which includes Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigations, and Emergency Contingency Plans.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



This is a non-responding Facility.   The Facility has coordinated emergency response activities with its LEPC and local fire department.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at this Facility.



CONCLUSION



The Risk Management Plan implemented by the Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The RMP will be updated as the Facility adds, deletes, or m

akes changes to the process. The Emergency Response Program has been coordinated with the Scott County LEPC and the North Scott Fire Department.  



NOTE: Sections 4, 5, 6, and 7 of the standard RMP produced by EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Facility.
